image.altText: A woman's hands hold a human skull.

props.synopsis: Laws banning the sale of human bones need to be reviewed to close "loopholes", legal experts say, amid a police probe into an auction house accused of selling skeletal remains.

title.children: Calls for crackdown on 'commodification of the dead'

image.altText: A large passenger bus is surrounded by police vehicles and a fire truck.

props.synopsis: Police say an intoxicated man entered a chartered coach loaded with passengers in Adelaide this morning and attempted to drive it away.

title.children: Four officers, police dog allegedly assaulted by man who boarded charter bus

image.altText: A man wearing a hat and glasses looks at a grapevine.

props.synopsis: Farmers in Australia's largest wine grape growing region are still counting losses from severe frost last month and there is no help on the horizon.

title.children: South Australian wine growers plead for help as frost 'disaster' hits 80 per cent of grapes

image.altText: old photo of young girl with older ladies projected onto large white silos with purple night sky and stars in background

props.synopsis: Decades after their last visit, three siblings have come back to the tiny wheatbelt town of their childhoods, with a projector in tow and a plan to wow their former community.

title.children: 'City slickers' welcomed by country town in 1968 return with an epic silo slide show

image.altText: A riverlea sign in the water

props.synopsis: The SA government gives developers of the Riverlea housing estate in Adelaide's north the green light to continue building, despite the discovery of Indigenous remains at the site last year.

title.children: Riverlea housing project to continue after discovery of Aboriginal remains

image.altText: Matilda Scholz, seen from behind, marks a ball high above the pack in an AFLW game.

props.synopsis: Matilda Scholz's stunning grab high above the Collingwood pack comes just minutes after Gemma Houghton's tight snap from the ruck in an AFLW win over Collingwood.

title.children: 'Unreal': Teen star takes stunning mark in Port Adelaide AFLW win

image.altText: Young girl leaning against window

props.synopsis: Essays aren't for everybody, and some students and teachers would like to see more flexible and creative approaches to learning to support those who are neurodivergent.

title.children: Neurodivergent students say 'more creativity in the curriculum' would transform their learning

image.altText: ASIO director-general Mike Burgess delivering a speech.

props.synopsis: At a summit examining the harmful effects of social media on child welfare, Mike Burgess delivered warnings about the ease with which young people could be radicalised online, and described the internet as the world's "greatest incubator" of extremism.

title.children: ASIO chief tells social media summit of 'disturbing resurgence' in youth terror cases

image.altText: Large storm clouds hang low over a house.

props.synopsis: Australia is facing one of the hottest summers on record according to the Bureau of Meteorology's weather modelling, which tips well-above-average temperatures across the country.

title.children: Our simmering oceans could mean the most active cyclone season in years, with the BOM forecasting a brutally hot summer

image.altText: Waves crash over Havana's seafront boulevard

props.synopsis: As Hurricane Milton causes widespread destruction, there's been talk of a seemingly unusual way of measuring its impact — the so-called "Waffle House Index", which maps storm severity in accordance with the impact on a fast food chain.

title.children: Why some are using waffle houses to measure the impact of Hurricane Milton

image.altText: Rocky Elsom at the 2011 Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: French media is reporting an international arrest warrant has been issued for Rocky Elsom — who captained the Wallabies between 2009 and 2011 — over his conduct as president of rugby union club Narbonne.

title.children: Ex-Wallabies captain reportedly facing international arrest warrant

image.altText: A glamorous-looking Indonesian woman and Australian man smile and pose for a photo while holding drinks.

props.synopsis: Essendon premiership player Ricky Olarenshaw's estranged wife Sarnanitha was arrested following a raid at the Flame Spa in Seminyak in early September.

title.children: Influencer wife of ex-AFL player arrested in Bali raids targeting illegal prostitution

image.altText: Cradle Mountain with Dove Lake in the foreground

props.synopsis: A 22-year old tourist has been assisted near Cradle Mountain, after attempting to climb the mountain sans footwear. It's prompted a reminder from police about the need to be properly prepared in the wilderness.

title.children: Hiker provided with assistance, and shoes, after attempting to climb Tasmanian mountain without them

image.altText: Middle-aged man and woman standing in front of two-storey timber beach style home with pool in front, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Prices in the small Queensland town of Keppel Sands have increased by 40 per cent in the past year, but this Victorian couple still think they got a great deal on a waterfront home.

title.children: Sleepy coastal town records first million-dollar property sale as buyers move interstate for bargains

image.altText: A middle-aged black woman in a suit waves as she steps onto a plane bearing the US vice-presidential seal.

props.synopsis: Dr Joshua Simmons, a US Army colonel and physician to the vice-president, wrote that Ms Harris, 59, maintains a healthy, active lifestyle and that she "possesses the physical and mental resiliency" required to serve as president.

title.children: Kamala Harris's doctor reports she's in 'excellent health', as her campaign looks to draw a contrast with Trump

image.altText: A sign that says TikTok with a window panel behind it.

props.synopsis: A significant number of employees in Malaysia are expected to be affected by the job cuts.

title.children: TikTok slashes hundreds of jobs in shift to AI-assisted content moderation

image.altText: Brodie Kostecki driving his Chevrolet Camaro during a practice session at the 2024 Bathurst 1000.

props.synopsis: A year on from starting at the top of the grid at Mount Panorama, Supercars champion Brodie Kostecki once again claims pole position for the Bathurst 1000.

title.children: Kostecki claims consecutive Bathurst 1000 poles

image.altText: A group people with a sign reading "white man fight back" near a stone cenotaph.

props.synopsis: The town of Corowa is just across the border from Victoria, where the use of Nazi salutes and symbols has been outlawed.

title.children: White supremacists rally in country NSW town, angering locals

image.altText: Alexei Navalny

props.synopsis: The former Russian opposition leader wrote on March 22, 2022: "I will spend the rest of my life in prison and die here."

title.children: Alexei Navalny's memoir reveals he thought he would die while serving his 19-year prison sentence

image.altText: A police sign on a Victoria Police car.

props.synopsis: It's alleged a sergeant performed the banned Nazi salute twice at the Victoria Police Academy this week.

title.children: Police sergeant suspended over Nazi salute allegations

image.altText: The tiger snake in central Melbourne pictured coiled in a gutter.

props.synopsis: Wildlife rescuers say urban sprawl and an unsettled spring are behind a sharp increase in call-outs in Melbourne at the start of snake breeding season.

title.children: Snakes no longer on the plains: Wildlife handlers inundated with sightings in the suburbs

image.altText: Two white wine glasses clinking

props.synopsis: When China lifted tariffs on Australia's bottled wine exports, winemakers, connoisseurs and importers were excited, but now they face new challenges and changing consumer behaviour.

title.children: China looks set to lift bans on Australian lobsters. Here's what happened to the last items to make it back in

image.altText: Anthony Albanese behind a podium.

props.synopsis: For Anthony Albanese and Labor, there hasn't been much to laugh about this week as war in the Middle East impacts politics at home, parliamentary gaffs and toxic staffer culture overshadow a worsening economic outlook.

title.children: When things are going badly in politics, even the wins end up feeling like losses for Anthony Albanese

image.altText: A piece of rusted metal laying on the sand at a tropical beach

props.synopsis: A 45-year-old inventor has bought a sought-after beachfront property, vowing to clear it of debris and rogue four-wheel drivers. But Labor has threatened to compulsorily acquire the land and it's taking that position to an election.

title.children: This coastal headland has just been sold to a private buyer. Could the Queensland government take it from him?

image.altText: Shoppers walk under a Catier watch advertisement.

props.synopsis: While Australian households are amongst the world's most indebted — courtesy of hefty mortgages — Chinese households are stacked to the rafters with savings. That sounds great, but it's causing real problems for the country's economy.

title.children: Beijing has finally opened the chequebook to save China's flagging economy. It may be too late

image.altText: The outside of an airplane labelled 'Boeing' on the ground

props.synopsis: The plane-maker has been plagued by safety concerns about its aircraft, while struggling to strike a deal with about 33,000 factory workers in the US.

title.children: Boeing to lay off 17,000 employees ahead of expected record losses

image.altText: A woman poses in front of a white banner with Korean words.

props.synopsis: Novelist Han Kang declines to hold a press conference after winning the Nobel literary award and says she can't celebrate the award while people die in wars, as her books sell out in major South Korean bookstores.

title.children: Han Kang declines press conference after Nobel win citing global wars, as her books sell out in South Korea

image.altText: Dozens of Indonesian soldiers in fatigues line up with rifles in hand

props.synopsis: The ABC gains rare access to Indonesia's West Papua province, speaking with Papuans ahead of the inauguration of Indonesia's new president — a former military general accused of historic human rights abuses.

title.children: A rare glimpse into West Papua and the war Indonesia does not want the world to see

image.altText: Renee is inside the cockpit flying a yet above the earth

props.synopsis: Going to Space Camp is something many kids can only dream about, but for these First Nations high-schoolers it’s become a reality. They’ll jet off to the States later this month to participate in science and technology workshops at the US Space and Rocket Centre.

title.children: 'Opens up a door I never really thought I had': First Nations teens off to NASA Space Camp

image.altText: A picture of three people, a boy and two women in a kitchen

props.synopsis: In a little clubhouse kitchen in Brisbane's suburban south, everyone has a story to tell — all are displaced Ukrainians who have fled the war and sought refuge in Australia.

title.children: Brisbane restaurant gives displaced Ukrainians a job and a second home

image.altText: A close up portrait of Miranda July who has curled auburn hair and blue eyes and is standing against a tiled wall

props.synopsis: All Fours threatens to shake up and change not only because of the quality of the writing but because July reaches deep and finds the small grain of universal truth at the heart of her fantastical story, so much that even its most unhinged parts start to seem possible.

title.children: Miranda July's All Fours is blowing up on group chats for good reason. It might even leave Germaine Greer in shock

image.altText: Two Hawthorn AFLW players embrace as they celebrate a goal against West Coast.

props.synopsis: Hawthorn moves to top spot on the ladder after thrashing West Coast by 66 points, while the Brisbane Lions and Richmond celebrate their respective victories.

title.children: Hawks dent Eagles' AFLW finals hopes, Lions hold off Suns for seventh straight win

image.altText: A satellite image of a massive hurricane cloud over the Gulf of Mexico

props.synopsis: When Hurricane Milton formed, it met with waters "as warm as a hot tub". As the world continues to burn fossil fuels and ocean temperatures climb, cyclonic storms feed off the heat and become bigger, faster and nastier.

title.children: Hurricane's intensification broke records and pushed 'limit allowable by physics'. Experts are shocked but not surprised
